imputeMiss

imputeMiss.Rmd
library(imputeMiss)

Introduction

Imputing Missing Values in Numerical Observations

Larger Amounts of Missing Data

When an observation contains >5% missing data, the mean/median replaces the missing values and a new binary column is created to track which rows were missing. In this example, the youngest_child columns is missing > 5% of observations in the tv dataset from qacbase.

In order to conserve space, only the first 10 rows are displayed:

library(qacBase)
#> Warning: package 'qacBase' was built under R version 4.0.5
ages <- tv$youngest_child
data.frame(youngest_child = head(ages, 10))
#>    youngest_child
#> 1              15
#> 2               7
#> 3              15
#> 4              NA
#> 5              NA
#> 6              NA
#> 7              17
#> 8               8
#> 9              NA
#> 10             NA
data.frame(
  youngest_child = head(imputeMiss(tv, method = "mean")[c("youngest_child",
                                                          "youngest_child_na")],
                        10))
#>    youngest_child.youngest_child youngest_child.youngest_child_na
#> 1                      15.000000                                0
#> 2                       7.000000                                0
#> 3                      15.000000                                0
#> 4                       7.497312                                1
#> 5                       7.497312                                1
#> 6                       7.497312                                1
#> 7                      17.000000                                0
#> 8                       8.000000                                0
#> 9                       7.497312                                1
#> 10                      7.497312                                1

The mean of this column is 7.497312

Missing Low Amounts of Data

If a numerical observation is missing a lower amount of data (< 5%) then we do a mean/median imputation on the missing data, the difference being there is no new column added, for this example, we demonstrate the mean option for the method parameter:

library(qacBase)
ages <- tv$youngest_child
data.frame(youngest_child = head(ages, 10))
#>    youngest_child
#> 1              15
#> 2               7
#> 3              15
#> 4              NA
#> 5              NA
#> 6              NA
#> 7              17
#> 8               8
#> 9              NA
#> 10             NA
data.frame(
  youngest_child = head(imputeMiss(tv, method = "median")[c("youngest_child",
                                                          "youngest_child_na")],
                        10))
#>    youngest_child.youngest_child youngest_child.youngest_child_na
#> 1                             15                                0
#> 2                              7                                0
#> 3                             15                                0
#> 4                              7                                1
#> 5                              7                                1
#> 6                              7                                1
#> 7                             17                                0
#> 8                              8                                0
#> 9                              7                                1
#> 10                             7                                1

The median is 7.0

Imputing Data in Categorical Data

One important thing to note is the imputeMiss function only imputes categorical data that is of the class factor, logical or character, so if you have a categorical variable that you wish to be imputed, it must be transformed into that type.

Missing Larger Amounts of Categorical Data

If a categorical variable has greater than 5% of its data missing, the string “Missing” is inserted everywhere there is missing data.

In the ‘tv’ dataset, the educ column is missing greater than 5% of its data and is a factor:

library(qacBase)
educ <- tv$educ
data.frame(educ = head(educ, 10))
#>    educ
#> 1    No
#> 2    No
#> 3   Yes
#> 4    No
#> 5  <NA>
#> 6  <NA>
#> 7    No
#> 8    No
#> 9  <NA>
#> 10 <NA>
data.frame(
  educ = head(imputeMiss(tv)[c("educ")],
                        10))
#>       educ
#> 1       No
#> 2       No
#> 3      Yes
#> 4       No
#> 5  Missing
#> 6  Missing
#> 7       No
#> 8       No
#> 9  Missing
#> 10 Missing

Missing Smaller Amounts of Categorical Data

If a categorical variable is missing less than 5% of its data, than the missing values are replaced with either the most frequent category or with a random sample

For this example we create a vector of size 100 of random sampled nums

column <- (sample(x = c(1, 3, 5, 7), size = 100, replace = TRUE))
column[1] <- NA
example_df <- data.frame(factor(column))
head(example_df, 10)
#>    factor.column.
#> 1            <NA>
#> 2               3
#> 3               1
#> 4               1
#> 5               5
#> 6               3
#> 7               7
#> 8               5
#> 9               7
#> 10              7
head(imputeMiss(example_df, method_cat = "frequent"), 10)
#>    factor.column.
#> 1               7
#> 2               3
#> 3               1
#> 4               1
#> 5               5
#> 6               3
#> 7               7
#> 8               5
#> 9               7
#> 10              7
head(imputeMiss(example_df, method_cat = "sample"), 10)
#>    factor.column.
#> 1               4
#> 2               3
#> 3               1
#> 4               1
#> 5               5
#> 6               3
#> 7               7
#> 8               5
#> 9               7
#> 10              7
